speaker: Waitress
text: Here you go Doc, your usual.

speaker: Frasier
text: My usual.  How lovely it is to have a usual. [_tastes it_] What is this?

speaker: Waitress
text: Latte with nutmeg and cinnamon.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, no, no, no, that's my brother's usual.  Mine is the double Kona with cream.

speaker: Niles
text: [_entering:_] Oh, Frasier, am I glad to see you.

speaker: Waitress
text: [_to Niles:_] Your usual, Doc?

speaker: Niles
text: Please. [_she hands Frasier's to Niles, then he carries on:_] Thank you!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you seem more than usually agitated today.  Problem?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm meeting my publisher here in five minutes.  Remember the book deal I signed last month, the one you were so jealous of?

speaker: Frasier
text: I wasn't jealous of it, Niles, you just wanted me to be jealous.

speaker: Niles
text: It's all moot anyway, the deal's about to be killed.  It turns out the idea I sold them had already been done.  They gave me until today to think up an alternative and I've got bupkes. I've got less than bupkes.  I've got what bupkes keeps for lint in the bottom of his pocket!

speaker: Frasier
text: Can't you just ask for an extension?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, I've asked for two already.  [_He sees the publisher walking in._]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh God there he is.  Sam, so good to see you.

speaker: Sam
text: Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Sam Tanaka, my brother Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: My pleasure. [_the waitress brings Frasier's coffee_]

speaker: Sam
text: Nice to meet you.

speaker: Niles
text: Sam, would you like a coffee?

speaker: Sam
text: [_points to Frasier's cup:_] Oh, I'll have what he's having. [_Niles takes Frasier's cup and gives it to Sam._]

speaker: Niles
text: So you shall.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to waitress:_] One more, please.

speaker: Sam
text: Wait a second, you're the doctor from the radio, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Guilty as charged.

speaker: Sam
text: I listen to your show all the time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you.

speaker: Sam
text: I never put it together that you two of you were brothers.

speaker: Niles
text: All our lives. [_laughs_]

speaker: Sam
text: Well, you two must have incredible insight into sibling relationships.

speaker: Frasier
text: No more than your average psychiatrist brothers. [_laughs_]

speaker: Sam
text: So Niles, what's your idea?

speaker: Niles
text: [_nearly crying:_] My idea... Well Sam, you know I've given it a lot of thought, and it's not easy...

speaker: Sam
text: You'd almost think there's a book in that.

speaker: Niles
text: In what?

speaker: Sam
text: Two psychiatrist brothers writing about sibling relationships.

speaker: Niles
text: That, Sam, is why you are the most respected publisher in the greater Seattle area.  That is exactly the idea we were going to pitch to you.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  I hate to interrupt...

speaker: Sam
text: Terrific!  Gentlemen, I'm going to cancel my lunch date so I can take you two out to celebrate.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we were going to write today, but OK.  [_Sam leaves._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what the hell are you doing?  I don't want to write a book.  For God's sake, I'm out of here.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I know it's asking a big favor.  I mean, I know you're busy.  But I want you to know that all of my life I've dreamed of one thing: the day I could go into a library and go to the card catalogue and see my name under "mental illness" - the day I could finally feel what you feel; that I'm somebody, not just one more dusty little psychiatrist in a grey pinstripe suit.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, I...

speaker: Niles
text: Come on!  We haven't collaborated on anything together since we wrote the spring musical in prep school.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it was well received.  And it did get us out of gym class.

speaker: Niles
text: It could be like that again.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know, Niles... _Niles starts humming the tune from their old musical; Frasier starts bouncing in rhythm to it._ _

speaker: Niles
text: Ump-da, ump-da, ump-da, da-da-da, ump-da, ump-da, ump-da...

speaker: Both
text: [_singing:_] Though some boys go to college, But we think they're all wussies, �Cause they get all the knowledge, And we get all the... [_dancing in a circle_] Ump-da, ump-da, ump-da, da-da-da, ump-da, ump-da, ump-da...

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, I'll do it!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes! **IT WAS PROBABLY LAKE SMITH**  _Scene Two -- Frasier's Apartment Later, Frasier answers the door to his partner, Niles. Martin is by the television._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dumas frere.

speaker: Niles
text: Dumas frere.

speaker: Martin
text: Hello Niles, what are you doing over here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Dad, I told you it's our first writing session tonight.

speaker: Martin
text: But I thought you were doing it over at Niles's house.

speaker: Niles
text: Er, we were supposed to.  Unfortunately, it's Maris's turn to host her sherry tasting group and things tend to get a little raucous when she does.

speaker: Martin
text: But "The Silencer"'s on in twenty minutes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I've solved that problem. _He produces a pair of wireless headphones, the type you can use to hear your television while the sound is muted._

speaker: Frasier
text: I've bought you these headphones, see?  You'll be able to listen to the TV, without disturbing Niles and me as we work.

speaker: Martin
text: What about Eddie?  How's he going to hear?

speaker: Frasier
text: He can read about the game in tomorrow's paper.  Try 'em out, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: [_shouts:_] Hey, not bad! [_watches the TV_]

speaker: Niles
text: Very clever solution.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and it also has another little feature that I like a lot.  Watch this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey, Dad!  Nice shirt.  Did they throw that in the last time you had your tires rotated?

speaker: Niles
text: Hey Dad?  Tell us about the time you met Dwight Eisenhower. We haven't heard that story this hour! [_they laugh again_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, okay, my turn.  Hey, Dad?  Remember-

speaker: Martin
text: [_obviously hearing:_] Say another word and I'll club you both with my cane. _The brothers hastily back off and sit at the dinner table.  Martin settles down to watch the TV._

speaker: Martin
text: This is great, thanks a lot. [_puts earphones around Eddie's neck_] You better watch out for this for me, Eddie.  I'm going to get myself a little snack.  Who wants some beer?

speaker: Frasier
text: Just you!  Alright now, Niles, this is no time to procrastinate.

speaker: Niles
text: [_poised at the keyboard of his laptop_] OK, here we go. Chapter One.  Page One.  Paragraph One.  I'm indenting!

speaker: Frasier
text: I hate to squash your enthusiasm, but don't you think before We start actually typing the book, we should discuss what the book is going to be about!

speaker: Niles
text: Forgive me for just barreling ahead, but damn it, I'm jazzed. You know we have to approach this book from a completely different angle from all of our previous writings, our dissertations, out theses...

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm, that's right.  Yeah, this has to be interesting!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, the obvious approach is case histories.  We'll fill the book with anecdotes with brothers and sisters we've dealt with in our practice.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and if we throw in a few references to heaving bosoms, we're bound to make Book of the Month Club.

speaker: Martin
text: Why, I could tell you a couple of stories about you guys you could throw in there.

speaker: Niles
text: That's an idea, we could use ourselves, it would make a delicious introduction to our book.

speaker: Frasier
text: I like the introduction idea.  Dad, OK, give us a story which depicts little Frasier and little Niles at their conflicted best.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that has to be when we went trout fishing up at that lake whats-its-name.  Boy, you guys were at it tooth and nail.

speaker: Niles
text: This is good, this is interesting.

speaker: Martin
text: Now, what was the name of that lake again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, the name of the lake is immaterial.

speaker: Martin
text: Indian word, Lake Whatchahatchi?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you're missing the point here.

speaker: Martin
text: [_ignoring:_] Oh, your mother would know.  Too bad she's dead! Er, whatacouchi, whatawoochi.  It was an Indian word, it meant "Land of a thousand..."  No!  This is driving me nuts!  I'm going to have to go in there and look it up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, we just wanted the story!

speaker: Martin
text: No, it's alright.  Now where the hell did I put my atlas? [_leaves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Quite a resource, isn't he?

speaker: Niles
text: Alright, we'll just put the introduction on hold.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, back to case histories.  Well, I suppose I could go take my files out of storage after the re... [_thinks of something_] Niles, is there a light bulb over my head?

speaker: Niles
text: You have an idea?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, [_sarcastically:_] I'm actually asking you if there's a light bulb over my head!  Of course I have an idea, it's my radio show.  I mean, what better source of case histories can there be?  I'll just ask my listeners to call in with their personal stories of sibling conflict, and you could be my guest on the show.

speaker: Niles
text: So, what you're suggesting, is that exploit your listeners' lives for our own personal game?

speaker: Frasier
text: In essence, yes.  What do you think?

speaker: Niles
text: I think it's borderline sleazy.  Let's go for it! **THE MOTHER LODE**  _Scene Three - KACL So, on the next day, Frasier is standing in Roz's booth, setting up for his show.  Niles is sitting to the side of his console, in front of the guest's mike.  Roz comes in and isn't too pleased._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Frasier.  What's your brother doing here?

speaker: Frasier
text: He's going to be my guest on the show today.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, no!  I don't think so!  I am the producer, and I approve all the guests.  This wasn't run by me and I do not approve him!

speaker: Frasier
text: OK, Roz, bye-bye, have a good show.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay, okay.  But I won't make him coffee, I won't run his Errands and I'm not taking any of his crapola. [_through mike:_] Hey, Niles, welcome aboard. [_to Frasier:_] Five seconds till air.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_into booth with Niles:_] OK, Niles, sit down, take a deep breath and try not to spit on the mike! [_on air:_] Hello Seattle, this is Dr. Frasier Crane.  I have a very special guest with me today - my brother, the eminent psychiatrist, Dr. Niles Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Emerald City!  What's doing, what's happenin'?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_off air:_] What the hell do you think you're doing?

speaker: Niles
text: That was my radio persona.  Every successful radio personality has one.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't.

speaker: Niles
text: My point exactly.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just try to be yourself, will you? [_on air:_] Our topic today is siblings: what makes you love them, what makes you hate them...

speaker: Niles
text: What little things do they do that especially annoy you? These could be things from your childhood OR they could things from your adolesence, OR they could be things from your young adulthood OR...

speaker: Frasier
text: They could be things that are going on right now!  Roz, who's our first caller?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Donald from Bainbridge Island.  He hasn't spoken to his brother for over twenty years.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Donald.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm listening!

speaker: Frasier
text: We're listening!  _Time Fade. The show is now nearing to a close.  A woman called Laura is on the line, talking to Frasier whilst Niles is scribbling down all the details._

speaker: Laura
text: [_v.o._] I'll never forget it, Dr. Crane, I cried for two hours straight.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, you were completely bald.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes, the perm destroyed my hair.  I was sure my sisters were going to laugh at me.  But, they all kissed me and then they marched into the bathroom and shaved their heads too, just so I wouldn't feel like a freak.

speaker: Frasier
text: Amazing!  Well, there you have it, Seattle - the miracle of the sibling relationship spelled out in an unselfish act of head-shaving.  Well, that's about all the time we have. I'd like to thank my brother Dr. Niles Crane for being here today.  Niles, I would shave my head for you.

speaker: Niles
text: A gesture which becomes less significant with each passing year. [_Roz hides a grin_]

speaker: Frasier
text: This is Dr. Frasier Crane, I'll be back tomorrow.  One Crane flying solo.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, we have hit the mother lode.  We've got enough information here for two volumes!  I must aplogise for ever criticizing your radio program.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, it's all water under the pont-neuf.

speaker: Roz
text: [_peering round:_] I hate to break up the stroke-a-thon, but there's a Sam Tanaka on line one.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_presses button_] Oh, hello Sam, you're on speakerphone.

speaker: Sam
text: I caught the show today, fellas.

speaker: Frasier
text: You did!  And?

speaker: Sam
text: Jackpot! [_Frasier and Niles make ecstatic faces at each other_] How's the writing coming?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, incredible, it's just falling like water.  We've got, what, two or three chapters already.

speaker: Sam
text: That's good to hear, because I just got off the phone with Reader's Digest.  They're interested in the serialization rights.  I need first few chapters to give them a taste, can you fax them right over?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Sam Of course we could, but you know, they're a little rough, Sam.

speaker: Sam
text: No problem, you've got till Friday to polish them up. You can do that, right?

speaker: Niles
text: Absolutely!

speaker: Frasier
text: Friday's fine!

speaker: Sam
text: Terrific, I love you guys! [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, what are we going to do?

speaker: Niles
text: Well now, let's remember we have all this material and now it's just a matter of putting it all together.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's due on Friday!

speaker: Niles
text: We'll settle down and do it by [_stressed:_] Friday!

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait, wait, I just remembered a story about George and Ira Gershwin when they had to meet a deadline.  They would lock themselves in a hotel room, free from distractions, and not come out until their task was complete.

speaker: Niles
text: Brilliant!  If we get hot we'll not only finish this volume but we can write another chorus to "Betsy Who Is My Woman Now."  _End of Act One (Time: 11:52)  Act Two._  **GEORGE AND IRA**  _Scene One -- Hotel Room The Crane boys arrive at their hotel room.  It's time to get to work. _

speaker: Niles
text: It's clean, it's sparkling, [_re: paintings on walls_] it's mass-produced art, it's totally devoid of charm - it's perfect.  Let's get to work.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm with you, mon frere.  We cannot be intimidated by the tyranny of a blank page.  All we need to get a good start here is... Room Service!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you're right!  All we need is a good opening sentence. Something that will smack the reader right between the eyes and then take him on a virtual roller-coaster ride of self awareness and discovery.

speaker: Niles
text: [_typing_] Frasier, while you were out there mixing metaphors like a Cuisinart, I've had a breakthrough.  Voila!  Our opening sentence!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading:_] "From Romulus and Remus to the Le Nain Sisters, sibling relationships have sparked psychological debate throughout the world." [_thinks_] Interesting.

speaker: Niles
text: You like it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I said it was interesting.  The task ahead of us now is to decide whether we'd like an interesting opening or a good one.

speaker: Niles
text: You're just being negative because you didn't think of it first.

speaker: Frasier
text: No!  In truth I'm not.  I never cared for Romulus, I never cared for Remus and the reference to the Le Nain Sisters is from the friggin' moon.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, alright, if you can do better, please be my guest.

speaker: Frasier
text: I will.

speaker: Niles
text: My fingers are poised over the keys... I'm waiting. _Some time later, Frasier and Niles have taken off their jackets, they are sitting in the same exact spot and Niles is still twiddling his thumbs above the keyboard.  They look more tired._

speaker: Niles
text: I'm still waiting!

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, alright, put this down!  "The key to a good sibling relationship is the ability to be open and honest."

speaker: Niles
text: That actually sounded good to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, put that in there.

speaker: Niles
text: [_typing:_] "The key to a good sibling relationship is the ability to be open and honest, while still respecting each other's boundaries."

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you doing?  What was that crap about boundaries?

speaker: Niles
text: I was just finishing the thought.

speaker: Frasier
text: The thought was finished.  It didn't need finishing, for God's sake.  Now it's a run-on sentence.

speaker: Niles
text: I think it's much better this way.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I don't!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm at the keyboard.

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright then, let me type!

speaker: Niles
text: No, I can only write at the keyboard.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you haven't written a thing all day, except to ruin a perfectly good opening sentence.

speaker: Niles
text: [_mad:_] I was merely finishing it, it was an incomplete thought.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're an incomplete thought!  What happened to the iced tea?

speaker: Niles
text: I finished that too! _Much later, both men are stripped down to their undershirts (Niles, of course, wears suspenders).  Frasier is lying on the bed, guzzling drinks from the mini bar.  Niles is barely awake over the keys, yawning._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I've just had an epiphany.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh wonderful, we could use a second sentence.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, it's not for the book.  I've just realised why so many writers become bloated alcoholic suicides. [_Niles types_] No, don't type that in.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm not, I'm adding up our tab from the mini-bar.  We now owe... two hundred thirty-two dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looks out of window._] Oh, Dear God!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you're the damn fool that ate the whole jar of Macadamia nuts!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, it's dawn.  It's Friday!  Oh Niles, why don't we just admit it.  We can't work together, there's never going to be any book!

speaker: Niles
text: [_brushing up hair:_] Not with that attitude, there isn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, will you get off it!  Come on, the fat lady has sung!  The curtain has been run down here.  I'll type it for you in capital letters! [_he does_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_reading:_] "IT'S UVER?"

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's just go home. _Frasier gets up and goes to the door, while Niles picks up a bottle that came from the mini-bar._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I guess I shouldn't be surprised you'd give up so easily.  It's not your dream, after all.  Why should it be, Mr. Bigshot Radio Host?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, so that's what this little tantrum is all about, huh? You're jealous of my celebrity?

speaker: Niles
text: It's not a tantrum, and I'm not jealous.  I'm just [_angry:_] FED UP!  I'm fed up with being second all the time.  You know, I wanted to be a psychiatrist like Mom way before you did, but because you were older you got there first.  You were first to get married.  You were first to give Dad the grandchild he always wanted.  By the time I get around to doing anything, it's all chewed meat!

speaker: Frasier
text: You're crying about something that we can't change!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you wouldn't change it if you could, you love it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, let it go, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: I can't let it go!  My nose is rubbed in it every day! four of _my_ patients have been elected to political office, but it's _your_ big fat face they put on the side of buses!

speaker: Frasier
text: I do not have a fat face!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh please, I've been wondering how long you're going to store those nuts for winter!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, at least I'm not SPINDLY!

speaker: Niles
text: Who you calling spindly, Fat Face?

speaker: Frasier
text: You, Spindly.

speaker: Niles
text: Fat Face!

speaker: Frasier
text: Spindly!

speaker: Niles
text: Fat Face!

speaker: Frasier
text: Spindly!

speaker: Niles
text: Fat Face!

speaker: Frasier
text: You take that back!

speaker: Niles
text: You make me.

speaker: Frasier
text: I will make you.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't see you making me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, here's making you...

speaker: Niles
text: OW! _Frasier turns toward the door.  Niles runs after him and jumps on his back.  Growling, Frasier spins around and slams Niles against the wall, twice.  Losing his wind, Niles drops off Frasier's back, and they grapple with their arms._

speaker: Niles
text: [_levering Frasier's chin_] Here's your fat face!  Gimme that-

speaker: Frasier
text: Gimme that- _As they wrestle, Niles gets the upper hand by placing Frasier in a headlock.  He laughs triumphantly._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  Niles!  Stop it!  We're psychiatrists, not pugilists!

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't believe you fell for that! [_seizes Niles in a headlock_] _Niles tries to break free, Frasier throws him onto the bed, then leaps onto him with a yell.  He starts to throttle Niles._

speaker: Niles
text: My God, my God, I'm having a flashback: you're climbing in my crib and jumping on me!

speaker: Frasier
text: YOU STOLE MY MOMMY!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God, oh my God.  Niles, I've gotta get out of here. This entire idea has been a fiasco since the start.  It's the stupidest idea you ever had, I should never have agreed to it!  Goodbye! _He grabs his briefcase and exits without bothering to get dressed. As he slams the door behind him, Niles, whipped, tumbles off the bed onto the floor.  FADE TO:  Scene Two -- Frasier's Apartment The next morning, Frasier enters the main room of his apartment where Martin and Daphne are sitting._

speaker: Frasier
text: Morning, all.

speaker: Martin
text: Morning.

speaker: Daphne
text: You seem cheerful this morning, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why shouldn't I be?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it's going to rain again, jobless rate's up, [_Frasier bites into a muffin_] and about two minutes ago Eddie was licking that muffin.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'll get it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, the mark of a pure man is that one that realizes he can't control his circumstances, he can only control his response.

speaker: Martin
text: Have you talked to your brother yet?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_going to kitchen_] I do not have a brother!  I'm an only child!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_answering door to Niles_] Oh, hello Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello Daphne, [_walks in_] Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Martin:_] Dad, I would like you to convey a message from me to Frasier.

speaker: Martin
text: What makes you think I know where he is?

speaker: Niles
text: Tell him, he owes me half this hotel bill.  Tell him I'll accept cash but no personal checks, as I know he has trouble writing things!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not paying any of this!

speaker: Niles
text: So, you're cheap as well as intellectually barren.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you're a no-talent hack.

speaker: Niles
text: And you look stupid in a t-shirt!

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, that's enough.  Sit down and listen to me.  Sit down. [_they do._] I never had a brother, but I had a partner once, my first, Mitch Gussy.  Big bear of a guy, arms like tree- trunks.  Mitch and I would go to ball games together, we'd play cards, and this was after work with eight hours together...

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, that's all very nice...

speaker: Martin
text: Just listen to me.  Three months into our partnership, Gus and I got assigned to a stakeout.  Three days in the front seat of a Chevy Nova together.  Sitting up, drinking too much coffee. It didn't take long before we started getting on each other's nerves.

speaker: Niles
text: Because he was a big, egotistical fat-face?

speaker: Martin
text: Because we were human.  He didn't like this about me, I didn't like that about him, so it got ugly.  When the stakeout was over Gus requested a transfer and that was fine by me.  Three months later, he was stabbed after breaking up a bar fight. By the time I got to the hospital, it was too late.

speaker: Martin
text: Take what you want from this story, guys.  All I know is, it ain't worth it.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_runs to the kitchen, crying:_] Excuse me, I need a hanky.

speaker: Martin
text: Isn't there something you'd like to say to your brother?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes Dad, I suppose there is. [_holding the muffin Eddie licked:_] Niles, would you like a muffin?

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright!  Niles, sorry things didn't work out with the book. You have no reason to feel inferior to me.  You're an accomplished psychiatrist, a decent man, and you stand second to no-one.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you Frasier.  The truth is, I've always looked up to you and admired you.

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, enough of this mushy girly stuff.  Just shake hands, punch each other on the shoulder and be done with it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, what the heck!  _Niles and Frasier hug, which just disappoints Martin.  Martin walks into the kitchen for a Ballantine and finds Daphne crying._

speaker: Martin
text: What are you crying about?

speaker: Daphne
text: I just keep thinking about poor Gus, it must be so hard on you carrying all that pain around.

speaker: Martin
text: There was no Gus, I just made him up.

speaker: Daphne
text: What?!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, at least there's one good writer in this family.
